Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(2) Summary

APIs are the foundation of many digital transformation initiatives. However, APIs come in many shapes and forms, and making the right design decisions is not an easy task. This becomes even more important in large organizations, where the challenge is to make good design decisions for individual APIs, while still making sure that there is a shared design culture across the organization's API landscape. This presentation takes a structured look at what matters for API design, and what good practices are when it comes to creating and managing an organizational API design culture.



How? Continuous Architecting!

(4) Interface Design



How? Continuous Architecting! Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(5) Interface Continuity and Evolution



How? Continuous Architecting! Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(6) API Products Evolve

  • APIs are consumed as a subscription-based activity
    • APIs may change even if the consumers did not change anything
    • Not breaking consumers is essential for scalable API management
  • API consumers can consume API products in different ways
    • Test servers can help consumers to validate their implementations
    • Production servers should focus on maximizing operational stability
    • Version freezes allow consumers to never worry about possible updates
  • Change Management [Change Management (1)] must be managed and communicated


How? Continuous Architecting! Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(7) API your APIs

  • Expose design-time and runtime API information in the API
    • Design-time allows automation of API landscape overview
    • Runtime allows automation of API landscape status
  • Follow robust extensibility principles [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] for these API APIs
    • Meaningful Core: Start with a simple but useful scenario
    • Extension Points: Think about how scenarios might evolve
    • Processing Model: Be clear about how extensions are handled


How? Continuous Architecting! Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(8) Emerging API Patterns

  • Self-description for APIs is increasing
  • Problem details [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/7807] as a way how APIs expose error information
    • Enables generic error handling but also allows additional information
  • Home documents [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/nottingham-json-home] as a way how APIs provide starting pages
    • Enables harvesting of API start points but also allows additional information
  • Healthcheck reports [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/inadarei-api-health-check] as a way how APIs expose status information
    • Enables landscape-level status reports but also allows additional information
  • API Labels [http://dret.net/lectures/apistrat-2018] as a way for representing API product labels
    • Share API labels as a way to describe cross-cutting aspects of APIs


API Styles

Outline (API Styles)

API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(10) Distributed Problem Solving

  • APIs are part of distributed problem solving
  • Ideal APIs can be used for a range of problems
  • Problem-solving often requires combining APIs
  • Language families make it easier to learn and use new APIs


API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(11) APIs Interactions Are Conversations

  • APIs support conversations between interacting peers
    • Some conversations are point-to-point (how to find the peer?)
    • Some conversations are point-to-multipoint (how are groups managed?)
    • Some conversations are point-to-ether (what does the ether do?)
  • API technology does not determine the API conversation style
    • HTTP can be used for asynchronous conversations (WebHooks [http://www.webhooks.org/] pattern)
    • Synchronous conversations can be layered on top of asynchronous foundations
  • Conversation goals should determine the conversation style


API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(12) API Style Metaphors

  • Tunnel Style: One Tunnel to Call them All [Tunnel Style: One Tunnel to Call them All (1)]: Function calls in procedural programming
  • URI Style: Listing All Resources [URI Style: Listing All Resources (1)]: Data access objects
  • Hypermedia Style: Linking All Resources [Hypermedia Style: Linking All Resources (1)]: Browsing the Web
  • Query Style: Querying into Server-Side Models [Query Style: Querying into Server-Side Models (1)]: Databases and database queries
  • Event-Based Style: Event Listening [Event-Based Style: Event Listening (1)]: Event-based programming


API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(18) Choosing an API Style



API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(19) API Context Considerations

  • Backend for Frontend (BFF) implies tight coupling producer/consumer
    • API style and API design can be coordinated with the consumer
  • Private APIs implies a smaller group of potential consumers
    • Style and design can be guided by internal guidelines/practices
  • Partner APIs implies a well-known group of consumers
    • Broader appeal to consumers necessary
  • Public APIs is the most loosely coupled group of consumers
    • No control over consumers and their preferences/tools and development cycles


API Styles Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(20) API Styles in the Wild

  • Tunnel Style: One Tunnel to Call them All [Tunnel Style: One Tunnel to Call them All (1)]: XML-RPC, SOAP, gRPC, Avro
  • URI Style: Listing All Resources [URI Style: Listing All Resources (1)]: OpenAPI/Swagger, RAML, API Blueprint
  • Hypermedia Style: Linking All Resources [Hypermedia Style: Linking All Resources (1)]: HAL, Siren, Atom, HATEOAS
  • Query Style: Querying into Server-Side Models [Query Style: Querying into Server-Side Models (1)]: GraphQL, OData, SPARQL
  • Event-Based Style: Event Listening [Event-Based Style: Event Listening (1)]: MQ, WebSub, MQTT, XMPP, AMQP, Kafka


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction

Outline (OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction)

  1. How? Continuous Architecting! [5]

  5. Conclusions [2]
OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(22) OpenAPI Basics

  • Swagger started as an easy way to generate code from an API description
    • Server code is generated by generating stubs for all specified URI paths
    • Client code generates SDKs for clients by wrapping API interactions
  • Swagger was renamed to OpenAPI at the beginning of 2016
    • Swagger still exists as a product suite [https://smartbear.com/] offered by SmartBear [https://swaggerhub.com/]
    • OpenAPI 3.0 [https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.0.md] is the first standalone OpenAPI version and was released in July 2017 [https://www.openapis.org/blog/2017/07/26/the-oai-announces-the-openapi-specification-3-0-0]
  • OpenAPI is focused on URI Style: Listing All Resources [URI Style: Listing All Resources (1)] APIs by modeling APIs as sets of URI paths
    • Paths can be templated and have operations and optionally parameters
    • JSON support is built into OpenAPI for request/response schemas
    • XML support is present but rather weak in terms of XML sophistication


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(23) JSON and YAML

  • JSON is the de-facto standard for structured data on the Web
  • JSON is human-readable but visibly comes from a code background
  • YAML [http://yaml.org/] evolved as a human-readable format for configuration data
    • JSON data can be written in YAML for a more human-friendly syntax
    • YAML has many additional features that JSON does not support
  • OpenAPI is defined in JSON and allows JSON and YAML representations


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(24) OpenAPI Info Object (JSON) 

{
  "title": "Sample Pet Store App",
  "description": "This is a sample server for a pet store.",
  "termsOfService": "http://example.com/terms/",
  "contact": {
    "name": "API Support",
    "url": "http://www.example.com/support",
    "email": "support@example.com"
  },
  "license": {
    "name": "Apache 2.0",
    "url": "https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html"
  },
  "version": "1.0.1"
}
  • openapi-info.json


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(25) OpenAPI Info Object (YAML) 

title: Sample Pet Store App
description: This is a sample server for a pet store.
termsOfService: http://example.com/terms/
contact:
  name: API Support
  url: http://www.example.com/support
  email: support@example.com
license:
  name: Apache 2.0
  url: https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html
version: 1.0.1
  • openapi-info.yaml


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(26) Minimal OpenAPI Example

  • Identification of the Swagger/OpenAPI version
  • Minimal metadata about the described API
  • URIs that are made available by the API
  • Operations that can be performed on these URIs
  • Responses to expect from these operations


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(27) Minimal OpenAPI Example (YAML) 

openapi: 3.0.0
info:
  title: Weather API
  version: 1.0.0
servers:
  - url: 'http://dret.net/weather'
paths:
  /forecast:
    get:
      summary: Get the weather forecast.
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Successful operation.
        '400':
          description: Invalid request.
        '500':
          description: Server error.
  • openapi-weather.yaml


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(28) Paths with Query Parameters

  • URIs with Query Parameters: /pets?limit=42
  /pets:
    get:
      summary: List all pets
      operationId: listPets
      tags:
        - pets
      parameters:
        - name: limit
          in: query
          description: How many items to return at one time (max 100)
          required: false
          schema:
            type: integer
            format: int32
  • petstore.yaml (line 10-23)


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(29) Paths with Path Parameters

  • URIs with Path Parameters: /pets/somepetname
  /pets/{petId}:
    get:
      summary: Info for a specific pet
      operationId: showPetById
      tags:
        - pets
      parameters:
        - name: petId
          in: path
          required: true
          description: The id of the pet to retrieve
          schema:
            type: string
  • petstore.yaml (line 56-68)


OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(30) OpenAPI/Swagger Editor



OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(31) OpenAPI: The Complete Picture



OpenAPI/Swagger Introduction Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(32) OpenAPI Summary: Describing URI Style APIs

  • OpenAPI describes APIs by listing all resource paths
  • OpenAPI is often used to generate server/client code
  • OpenAPI creates a static and tightly coupled API landscape
  • Evolving OpenAPI APIs is not a core part of OpenAPI's mission


Change Management

Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(34) Versioning Breaks Things



Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(35) Plan for Evolution

  • Planning for evolution means to reduce pain in the future
    • No immediate benefits other than doing the right thing
    • Modest effort when part of the API design process and culture
  • Extensibility should be part of the API design culture
    • Each API must have and document a plan for API evolution
    • The simplest possible plan may be to never change the API
  • Extensibility should be made easy for API consumers


Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(36) Robust Extensibility 1: Meaningful Core

  • The core of the API allows clients to have meaningful interactions
    • The starting point of an API should be meaningful and complete
  • The core of the API is robust over time
    • Anything that is added to the core does not change the core semantics
  • Anything that is not part of the core can be safely ignored
    • mustIgnore semantics allow safe interactions beyond closely coordinated groups


Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(37) Robust Extensibility 2: Extension Points

  • APIs should be clear about where extensions are allowed
    • API metamodels often decide where (potential) extension points are
    • API schemas/definitions should further narrow down where extensions are allowed
  • API tests can make sure that the extension points are properly implemented
    • Extensions in allowed places are ignored and tests should succeed
    • Extensions in other places should raise errors about malformed content
  • Extension points are interesting to support in generic software
    • Monitoring can report which and where extensions are being used
    • Libraries can make it easy to create/parse extension data


Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(38) Robust Extensibility 3: Processing Model

  • Extensions are well-defined and their handling is well-defined as well
    • Extension points make it clear where to expect extensions
    • Processing models make it clear what to do with extensions
  • mustIgnore is a popular and good choice for extension processing
    • Some formats allow extensions to declare their processing model (such as mustUnderstand)
    • HTML has a rule of ignoring unknown elements but processing their content
  • How to learn about extensions is a different matter


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design

(40) Design Matters

  • API design is a critical component of every API strategy
  • API design is necessary but not sufficient for a successful API program
    • Bad API design can undermine API success and destabilize API landscapes
    • Successful APIs provide access to products that have value for clients
  • Invest in API design and API landscaping and solicit feedback from product teams


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Design
